item.title: Atlantic City Black Business Directory: Empowering Local Entrepreneurs
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Black Business Directory celebrates and uplifts Black entrepreneurs across the city, fostering visibility, collaboration, and empowerment. It serves as both a resource and a movement — highlighting the creativity, resilience, and strength of Atlantic City’s Black business community.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City is taking a bold step toward inclusivity and economic empowerment with the launch of the Atlantic City Black Business Directory, a comprehensive guide that highlights and supports the city’s thriving community of Black-owned businesses.

This new initiative was developed to promote equity, visibility, and opportunity within Atlantic City’s business landscape. It brings together a growing network of entrepreneurs who are not only driving economic progress but also shaping the city’s vibrant cultural identity.

The Atlantic City Black Business Directory serves as a centralized resource for residents, visitors, and organizations seeking to support local businesses. Within its pages, readers will find listings that range from restaurants and boutiques to professional services, wellness providers, and creative enterprises — all owned and operated by Black entrepreneurs who are making a difference in their communities.

Beyond its practical purpose, the directory stands as a celebration of Black excellence and entrepreneurial resilience. It tells the story of determination, creativity, and leadership — reflecting the hard work of individuals who continue to uplift their neighborhoods while contributing to Atlantic City’s growth.

Each entry includes essential information such as business names, contact details, and service offerings, making it easier than ever for the public to connect directly with local entrepreneurs. The goal is simple yet powerful: to make supporting Black-owned businesses both intentional and accessible.

The project was made possible through partnerships with community organizations such as Better Tomorrows, which continues to play a leading role in initiatives that strengthen economic mobility and social equity. Together, these efforts emphasize not just awareness but collective action — a call for the community to stand behind the businesses that reflect its diversity and resilience.

By using and sharing the directory, residents and visitors are encouraged to practice intentional spending, ensuring their purchases contribute to sustainable growth and generational wealth within the Black business community. Every transaction becomes an investment — not only in individual businesses, but in Atlantic City’s future.

The release of this guide marks the beginning of a movement toward greater inclusion and community collaboration. As Atlantic City continues to evolve, initiatives like the Black Business Directory remind us that true progress happens when opportunity is shared and every voice is heard.

Those interested in exploring the directory can now access the full Atlantic City Black Business Directory online through this link:

‍View the Directory Here.

It’s an open invitation to discover, support, and celebrate the creativity, excellence, and entrepreneurial spirit that make Atlantic City shine.

item.title: Free Atlantic City Programs Empowered Residents and Entrepreneurs to Succeed
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City hosted a series of free workshops in November 2025 to help residents enhance their career prospects and support local entrepreneurs. Through initiatives like the Resume Building Workshop, Path to Employment Workshop, and Media Skills for Entrepreneurs, the city continued empowering its community for long-term success.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, under the leadership of Mayor Marty Small, Sr., continued its mission to empower residents by offering free programs designed to enhance career readiness and support local business growth. Through partnerships with community organizations and development offices, the city hosted a series of workshops and seminars in November 2025 that helped participants gain valuable skills and opportunities.

One of the highlighted initiatives was the Resume Building Workshop held on November 12th. Organized by the City of Atlantic City’s Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program under the CDBG office, in collaboration with Jewish Family Service (JFS), the event guided participants in creating professional resumes, discovering job leads, and receiving targeted training to increase employability. A follow-up session was also scheduled for December 9th at the PAL Building.

The Path to Employment Workshop, conducted on November 13th at the AtlantiCare Medical Arts Pavilion, brought together the City of Atlantic City Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program and Midtown CDC to provide comprehensive guidance on job preparedness. The workshop focused on helping residents boost confidence, explore career options, and strengthen their résumés. Participants also had another opportunity to join a similar workshop on December 18th.

For local entrepreneurs, the Media Skills for Entrepreneurs seminar offered practical training in public relations and brand promotion. Hosted by the City of Atlantic City Economic Development Office as part of the Planning and Development Seminar Series, this workshop took place on November 13th at Beat the Daily Grind Cafe. Attendees learned how to write compelling press releases, connect with media professionals, and strategically build brand visibility.

These programs reflected the city’s ongoing efforts to provide accessible and impactful learning opportunities. By collaborating with local organizations, Atlantic City demonstrated its strong commitment to fostering personal and professional growth among its residents.

The series not only supported job seekers but also created pathways for small business owners to thrive in the local economy. With resources like these, participants were able to enhance their skills and confidence, setting the stage for greater success in their respective fields.

Through consistent initiatives like the Planning and Development Seminar Series, the city proved that community collaboration and accessible education can create lasting change. Each session was a step forward in promoting economic development and empowering individuals to take control of their future.

By offering workshops focused on real-world needs—such as resume writing, job readiness, and media engagement—the City of Atlantic City continued to pave the way for a stronger, more connected community.

Residents who participated left equipped with the tools to pursue better opportunities, while entrepreneurs gained insights that would help their businesses stand out and grow sustainably.

These free programs exemplified Atlantic City’s dedication to supporting every member of the community—whether entering the workforce, changing careers, or growing a business.

item.title: Honoring Service: Atlantic City Held a Veterans Tribute at Jackson Avenue and the Boardwalk
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City held a heartfelt ceremony at Jackson Avenue and the Boardwalk to honor the men and women who served the nation. In observance of Veterans Day, all city buildings were closed on November 11.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City gathered over the weekend for a heartfelt ceremony at Jackson Avenue and the Boardwalk to honor the brave men and women who had served the nation. Residents, community leaders, and veterans came together in a moment of unity and gratitude, reflecting on the sacrifices made by service members throughout the years.

The ceremony offered a space for reflection and appreciation, allowing attendees to pay tribute to those who dedicated their lives to protecting the country’s freedoms. Local officials emphasized the importance of recognizing veterans not only on designated holidays but throughout the year, acknowledging the continued contributions they made to the community.

In observance of Veterans Day, the City of Atlantic City announced that all municipal buildings would be closed on November 11. This closure served as a reminder of the significance of the day and offered residents additional time to honor and reflect on the service of veterans.

The gathering highlighted Atlantic City’s ongoing commitment to honoring those who served, ensuring their legacy remains central to the community’s values and traditions.

item.title: Honoring a Legacy: John Bucci Corner Officially Dedicated in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City officially dedicated John Bucci Corner at Texas and Fairmount Avenues, honoring the legacy of the man known as “Mr. Atlantic City.” The ceremony brought together city leaders, residents, and the Bucci family to celebrate his lasting impact on the community.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City formally honored one of its most beloved community figures with the dedication of John Bucci Corner at the intersection of Texas and Fairmount Avenues. Known affectionately as “Mr. Atlantic City,” John Bucci left an enduring legacy that city officials, residents, and his family came together to celebrate during Friday’s unveiling ceremony.

City leaders joined the Bucci family to reveal the new street sign, a tribute to the man many remember as “John John.” His influence stretched across generations, touching the lives of countless residents through his kindness, generosity, and unwavering commitment to the community he loved deeply.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. described Bucci as “one of the nicest human beings to ever grace the planet Earth,” expressing the profound respect and affection shared by so many who knew him. His words reflected the sentiment felt throughout the crowd, which had gathered to honor a life defined by service and compassion.

Throughout the ceremony, attendees shared stories of Bucci’s lasting impact—from supporting local businesses to uplifting neighborhood initiatives and offering a helping hand to anyone in need. These recollections painted a portrait of a man whose dedication to Atlantic City extended far beyond titles or recognition.

The newly designated John Bucci Corner served as a visible symbol of his contributions. More than just a sign, it represented the values he lived by and the positive imprint he left on the city’s cultural and civic landscape.

City officials emphasized that the dedication stood as a permanent reminder of Bucci’s legacy and the example he set for civic pride and community involvement. The Bucci family expressed heartfelt gratitude to the city for commemorating him in such a meaningful and lasting way.

As the ceremony concluded, a sense of unity and remembrance filled the intersection. Through this dedication, Atlantic City ensured that John Bucci’s name, spirit, and legacy would continue to inspire residents and future generations for years to come.

item.title: November 2025 Great Day Gazette: Revitalizing, Celebrating, and Honoring Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: November was a month of revitalization, celebration, and community pride in Atlantic City. From major infrastructure upgrades to cultural recognition and heartfelt local events, the Great Day Gazette captured how the city continued to grow stronger together.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City continued its revitalization efforts this November, focusing on infrastructure, community connection, and celebration. Major updates, new programs, and heartwarming stories shaped another great month in the city’s journey toward progress and unity.

The city’s infrastructure saw significant improvements as Pacific Avenue joined the paving program, aligning with the ongoing Atlantic Avenue repaving project. The initiative was strengthened by a total of $5.3 million in NJDOT grant funding, supporting road enhancements and synchronized traffic signal upgrades across key corridors. Additionally, $684,708 was allocated for new pedestrian sidewalks along the Black Horse Pike, improving safety for students and families traveling between Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights.

Progress was also visible in other neighborhoods. The Baltic Avenue paving project neared completion, while the MLK Boulevard upgrade moved into the milling and paving phase. Meanwhile, construction reviews were underway for the Atlantic Avenue paving from Tennessee to Albany Avenues—marking another milestone in the city’s ongoing development plan.

Community spaces also came back to life with the long-awaited grand opening of Weekes Memorial Park. After years of careful restoration, this park once again became a welcoming gathering space for residents. The redesign featured landscaping, artistic displays, sustainable features, and accessibility upgrades, symbolizing the city’s commitment to safety, inclusion, and green living.

Listening to resident feedback, the Public Works Department installed additional stop signs at Winchester and Dover Avenues to ensure improved pedestrian and traffic safety—another example of how the city acted on community input to enhance neighborhood well-being.

The city celebrated the season with family-friendly festivities. Harvest Town filled Gardner’s Basin with music, games, costumes, and community resource tables, bringing together families for an afternoon of fun and connection. Likewise, Senior Services hosted a pumpkin decorating event, adding creativity and color to the fall spirit.

Fall evenings came alive at Bader Field during the Drive-In Movie & S’mores Night, where families gathered under the crisp night sky to enjoy a family film, fires, and free refreshments. The event also provided free winter hats and gloves, ensuring everyone stayed warm while celebrating together. Meanwhile, Atlantic City Recreation wrapped up another successful T-ball season, helping young athletes learn teamwork and skill in a positive environment.

Acts of heroism and recognition took center stage this month as well. The Atlantic City Police Foundation Hero Luncheon honored Sgt. Jonathan Walsh for saving a swimmer from drowning and Treasurer James Kutch for his years of dedicated service. During the same period, Officer Matt Schmidt received national attention for rescuing an injured canine from the icy October bay waters, showcasing the bravery and compassion of the city’s first responders.

Atlantic City also paid tribute to Rita and Anthony Mack, longtime business owners and community leaders, by dedicating a section of Arctic Avenue in their honor. For nearly four decades, the Macks provided employment, mentorship, and opportunities to countless residents through their McDonald’s franchises, making a lasting impact on the community they loved.

The city’s diversity and unity were celebrated as Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the Office of Multicultural Services received the Diaspora Excellence Award from Rediscover Africa 2025 and the Ghanaian Associations of South Jersey and Atlantic City. The recognition reflected the city’s ongoing commitment to cultural inclusion and the success of historic events like the Ghana Flag Raising Ceremony—the first of its kind in New Jersey.

November also emphasized health and wellness through the Pink Walk for a Purpose, a citywide event for Breast Cancer Awareness Month, where employees joined together to walk in support of survivors and ongoing fighters. Meanwhile, the Re-Entry Services Division held a family reunification event at the All Wars Memorial Building, providing food, fun, and creative activities that brought families closer together.

Finally, Atlantic City Youth Services launched an empowering martial arts program, teaching children the 3 S’s—Self-confidence, Self-reliance, and Self-defense—as part of a series of exciting fall programs designed to engage the city’s youth in positive growth and discipline.

From infrastructure renewal and community celebrations to acts of heroism and cultural recognition, November 2025 stood as another milestone month for Atlantic City—reminding everyone that every day truly is a Great Day in Atlantic City.

item.title: A Week of Learning and Cultural Celebration
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Our week was filled with learning and celebration—from mastering Spanish phrases in class to sharing Vietnamese spring rolls at the Multicultural Festival at Atlantic Cape Community College.
item.content:encoded:
This past week was filled with both learning and cultural connection for our team and students. During our third week of Intro to Spanish, students continued to build their language skills by learning how to talk about their families, use negative phrases, and form simple two-word sentences. Each class brought new opportunities for growth, confidence, and fun—¡muy bien!

Beyond the classroom, our team had the pleasure of joining the Multicultural Festival at Atlantic Cape Community College, hosted by Oceanside I Family Success Center. It was a wonderful celebration of diversity and togetherness, where we proudly shared Vietnamese spring rolls and enjoyed performances and food representing cultures from all around the world.

The event was not only a feast for the senses but also a meaningful reminder of the beauty of unity through cultural exchange. Attendees got to experience music, dance, and cuisines that highlighted the community’s rich cultural tapestry.

It was truly a fulfilling week—one that reminded us of the joy of learning something new and celebrating the cultures that bring us together.

item.title: Atlantic City Detectives Complete Specialized Crime Scene Investigation Training
item.dc:creator: Great Day Altantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department congratulated Detectives Brian McKinney and Bryan Victoria-Garcia for completing the New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course, further strengthening the department’s investigative and forensic capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department extended its congratulations to Detectives Brian McKinney and Bryan Victoria-Garcia for the successful completion of the New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course.

Over the course of eight weeks, both detectives underwent extensive training designed to deepen their expertise in crime scene analysis and forensic evidence handling. The program covered a wide range of specialized topics including bloodstain pattern analysis, shooting analysis and reconstruction, forensic photography, fingerprint classification and recognition, grave extraction, evidence collection, and courtroom testimony.

This advanced training equipped the detectives with the technical skills necessary to interpret complex crime scenes and present clear, accurate findings in court proceedings.

The New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course is known for its rigorous curriculum and hands-on approach, emphasizing the highest standards of forensic science and investigative integrity.

Detectives McKinney and Victoria-Garcia’s participation in this program reflects their commitment to professional development and excellence in law enforcement. Their new skills will play a key role in supporting ongoing investigations and enhancing the department’s ability to bring justice to victims and their families.

With this achievement, the Atlantic City Police Department continues to strengthen its Investigations Division, which now includes multiple detectives trained in specialized forensic techniques.

By investing in continued education and advanced training, the department reaffirms its dedication to maintaining professionalism, precision, and accountability in all investigative operations.

The ACPD commended the detectives for their hard work and dedication, recognizing that their efforts not only elevate the department’s capabilities but also build greater trust and confidence within the Atlantic City community.

The completion of this program marks another step in the department’s ongoing mission to apply modern investigative science in the service of public safety.

Through teamwork, education, and continuous growth, the Atlantic City Police Department remains committed to excellence in protecting and serving the city’s residents.

item.title: Get Ready to Spark the Season! Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Village Coming This December 13
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City will sparkle with holiday spirit on December 13, as the Holiday Parade & Village brings festive floats, live entertainment, and a lively Holiday Market to O’Donnell Park — a night of magic and community celebration for all.
item.content:encoded:
The holidays are about to shine even brighter in Atlantic City! The City of Atlantic City, in partnership with Good Time Tricycle Productions and Jon Henderson, is bringing festive magic to the shore with the Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Village — a joyful celebration happening on Friday, December 13, 2025, starting at 4:00 PM.

A Parade Bursting with Holiday Cheer

The celebration begins with the Atlantic City Holiday Parade, stepping off from City Hall and making its way down Atlantic Avenue. Expect a spectacular lineup of festive floats, marching bands, costumed performers, and community groups filling the streets with holiday music, color, and excitement. From start to finish, the event promises to capture the heart of Atlantic City’s community spirit.

A Holiday Village Full of Wonder

The festivities continue at O’Donnell Park, where the Holiday Village and Market will come alive from 4 PM to 8 PM. Guests can explore local vendors, shop for handcrafted gifts, and enjoy seasonal bites and hot drinks while taking in the glow of twinkling lights. Families will love photos with Santa & Krampus, live performances, and the warm, festive energy that makes this night feel like a scene from a holiday movie.

A Night for Everyone

Whether you’re a resident or just visiting for the weekend, this free, family-friendly event offers the perfect way to celebrate the season. Bring your family, gather your friends, and line the streets to experience a holiday parade like no other—filled with lights, laughter, and lasting memories.

Be Part of the Celebration

Community groups, schools, and local businesses are invited to join in the fun! You can:
• Register a float and participate in the parade, or
• Apply to be a vendor at the Holiday Market and share your products, crafts, or treats with the community.

Here’s how to get involved:

  • Parade Application: https://bit.ly/47CO66Z
  • Holiday Market Application: https://bit.ly/3WEzfnx

A Celebration of Community and Local Pride

The Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Village is more than an event—it’s a celebration of togetherness, creativity, and hometown pride. Each float, performance, and vendor represents the heart of Atlantic City and the people who make it special.

Mark your calendars for Friday, December 13, 2025, at 4:00 PM, and get ready for an evening filled with lights, laughter, and local cheer. Come for the parade, stay for the market, and leave with hearts full of holiday joy and Atlantic City pride.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Enjoyed a Fun and Educational Soap and Loofah-Making Workshop
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services, in partnership with CROPS Nonprofit, hosted a Soap and Loofah-Making Workshop for local seniors. The event was a mix of learning, laughter, and creativity—proving that fun and education go hand in hand at any age.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Senior Services team successfully hosted another engaging and educational activity for the community’s older adults. This time, seniors participated in a Soap and Loofah-Making Workshop that blended creativity, learning, and fun.

Partnering with CROPS Nonprofit, the program aimed to provide seniors with an opportunity to explore new hobbies while fostering social connections and hands-on learning experiences. The collaboration reflected a shared commitment to promoting health, creativity, and lifelong learning within Atlantic City’s senior community.

Participants were delighted to discover that loofahs are actually plants, similar to cucumbers, and not sea sponges as many had believed. The session sparked curiosity and laughter as attendees shaped, mixed, and created their own personalized soaps and loofahs.

The event was filled with smiles and camaraderie, proving once again that learning can be both fun and fulfilling at any age. Many seniors expressed appreciation for the chance to engage in a new, enriching activity alongside friends and fellow community members.

Through programs like this, Atlantic City Senior Services continues to demonstrate its dedication to enriching the lives of local seniors. The initiative not only encourages creativity but also helps strengthen community bonds through shared experiences.

As with all their events, the day emphasized the importance of keeping minds active and spirits high—reminding everyone that the joy of discovery never fades.

The partnership with CROPS Nonprofit played a vital role in making the workshop possible, reinforcing how local collaborations can positively impact the community.

The workshop ended with seniors proudly displaying their handmade soaps and loofahs, celebrating both their creations and the memories made together.

Atlantic City Senior Services continues to look forward to more informative, educational, and fun programs designed to engage and uplift the city’s senior residents.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Reminded Residents to Fall Back and Stay Safe as Daylight Saving Time Ended
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City marked the end of Daylight Saving Time with a timely reminder for residents to set their clocks back one hour and review essential safety measures, including testing smoke detectors and updating emergency plans.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City reminded residents to take note of the time change as Daylight Saving Time officially ended at 2:00 AM on November 2nd. The city encouraged everyone to set their clocks back one hour before going to bed to ensure they stayed on schedule and enjoyed an extra hour of rest.

As part of this seasonal reminder, the City also used the occasion to highlight important home safety practices that should be reviewed during the time change. Residents were urged to test their smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, ensuring that these critical devices were in proper working condition.

In addition, the city recommended that everyone replace old batteries in detectors and other safety devices to help prevent potential hazards. The reminder also extended to checking flashlights and emergency kits, making sure families were well-equipped for any unexpected situation.

The City of Atlantic City encouraged residents to go a step further by reviewing their home safety plans, ensuring every household member knows what to do in case of an emergency. According to the city, this simple routine—coinciding with the clock adjustment—serves as an ideal time to refresh safety habits and strengthen preparedness.

By combining the Fall Back reminder with practical safety advice, the city emphasized the importance of preparedness and awareness within the community. Officials noted that taking just a few minutes to check detectors, update batteries, and review emergency plans could make a significant difference in keeping families safe.

The message served not only as a helpful time adjustment notice but also as a community-wide call to action for safety and readiness. As Atlantic City residents fell back into standard time, they were reminded to stay safe, stay prepared, and take advantage of that extra hour to rest easy knowing their homes and families were protected.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services Wrapped Up Breast Cancer Awareness Month with Unity and Support
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services concluded Breast Cancer Awareness Month with two inspiring Wear Pink Days at City Hall and the Public Safety Building, uniting the community to honor survivors, remember those lost, and encourage early detection.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services proudly wrapped up Breast Cancer Awareness Month by uniting city employees and community members in a meaningful display of strength, compassion, and solidarity. Throughout the month of October, the department led awareness efforts to honor survivors, remember those lost, and stand with individuals still fighting breast cancer.

In an inspiring show of community spirit, two Wear Pink Days were organized—one held at the City Hall Lobby and another at the Public Safety Building. Both events turned spaces into vibrant seas of pink as participants came together to support the cause and raise awareness about the importance of early detection and prevention.

The City Hall Lobby event drew employees and visitors who proudly wore pink attire, symbolizing unity and hope. It served as a moment to reflect on the power of collective action and the difference awareness can make in saving lives through timely screenings and education.

The second Wear Pink Day at the Public Safety Building carried the same energy of compassion and encouragement, with members of the public and city staff standing shoulder to shoulder in recognition of those affected by breast cancer. The event highlighted the city’s dedication to community wellness and its commitment to supporting initiatives that promote health and awareness.

Throughout the campaign, the Multicultural Services team emphasized the importance of awareness and education as vital tools in the ongoing fight against breast cancer. By hosting these events, they not only raised visibility for the cause but also created safe spaces for conversation, reflection, and empowerment.

As Breast Cancer Awareness Month came to a close, the department extended heartfelt thanks to everyone who participated, wore pink, and helped spread the message of hope and resilience. Their collective efforts reinforced the idea that every act of support—no matter how small—contributes to a larger movement of care and awareness.

The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services reaffirmed its commitment to continue supporting meaningful community initiatives that inspire action, foster awareness, and bring people together for the greater good.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Officer Matt Schmidt Featured Nationally for Heartwarming Dog Rescue
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department celebrated Officer Matt Schmidt, whose rescue of an abandoned dog earned national recognition on ABC News Live. His compassion and dedication made Atlantic City proud and highlighted the humanity behind the uniform.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department proudly recognized Officer Matt Schmidt after his inspiring act of compassion captured both local and national attention. His story of rescuing an abandoned dog touched hearts across the community and soon reached audiences nationwide.

What began as a routine day on duty turned into a powerful reminder of the compassion and humanity behind the badge. Officer Schmidt’s quick action and empathy ensured the safety and well-being of a vulnerable animal in need, reflecting the department’s deep commitment to service beyond enforcement.

Following the rescue, the story quickly gained traction in local news, resonating with residents and showcasing the positive impact of community policing.

The recognition reached new heights when Officer Schmidt was featured nationwide on ABC News Live. His segment aired at 11 AM on Friday, October 31st, sharing his story with viewers across the country and making Atlantic City proud on a national stage.

The department celebrated this achievement, noting how Officer Schmidt’s actions exemplified the values of compassion, dedication, and integrity that define the Atlantic City Police Department.

Colleagues and community members praised Officer Schmidt for his kindness and professionalism, applauding the way he represented both the department and the city with pride.

This national spotlight served as an important reminder of the everyday acts of service performed by officers who go above and beyond for their communities—often in ways that extend far beyond their official duties.

The Atlantic City Police Department expressed gratitude for the positive attention brought to the city, recognizing how moments like this strengthen the bond between officers and residents.

item.title: Join the Fun! Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market Set for December 13
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s annual Holiday Parade is back and this year it’s bigger, brighter, and more magical than ever. With a new date, a new route along Atlantic Avenue, and a brand-new Holiday Market at O’Donnell Memorial Park, this year’s celebration promises festive fun, local shopping, and community spirit that will light up the city all season long.
item.content:encoded:
The holiday season in Atlantic City is about to get even more magical. The City of Atlantic City's beloved Holiday Parade is returning this year with new surprises, a fresh route, and a brand-new Holiday Market that promises to fill the city with festive cheer, community spirit, and plenty of reasons to celebrate.

A Parade That Ends in Pure Holiday Magic

This year’s Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market will bring together everything locals love about the season, music, lights, local vendors, and joyful energy.

After the parade, the celebration continues at O’Donnell Memorial Park, where a new Holiday Market will showcase local artisans, handcrafted gifts, festive bites, and seasonal refreshments. Picture twinkling lights, the smell of hot chocolate, and neighbors greeting one another while supporting small businesses — it’s a scene straight out of a holiday movie, right here in Atlantic City.

New Date, Same Holiday Spirit

This year’s parade has been rescheduled to Saturday, December 13, 2025, when, beginning at 4:30 PM, the city will be glowing with holiday lights, creating the perfect backdrop for glowing floats, marching bands, community groups, and dazzling performances. Families are encouraged to bundle up, grab a cup of cocoa, and line the streets to watch Atlantic City come alive with the sights and sounds of the season.

New Route, More Convenience for Families

The parade will travel down Atlantic Avenue from South Carolina Avenue to Albany Avenue, with the staging area at City Hall.

This streamlined route connects directly to O’Donnell Memorial Park, making it easier for families to attend both the parade and the Holiday Market without cross-city travel. It’s a thoughtful touch that ensures everyone can enjoy the festivities together — all in one festive stretch of Atlantic Avenue.

Be Part of the Celebration

Calling all community groups, schools, and local businesses — there’s still time to get involved!
You can:

  • Register a float to join the parade, or
  • Apply to be a vendor at the Holiday Market to showcase your products, crafts, or treats.

To sign up, contact the City of Atlantic City Special Events Office at (609) 347-5823 or visit www.acnj.gov for registration forms.

A Celebration of Community and Local Pride

The Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market is more than an event — it’s a celebration of togetherness. From community organizations and small businesses to families and visitors, everyone plays a part in making this annual tradition shine brighter each year.

Mark your calendars for Saturday, December 13, 2025 at 4:30 PM, and experience the magic of the season — right here in Atlantic City. Come for the parade, stay for the market, and leave full of holiday joy and Atlantic City pride.

item.title: Atlantic City Made Steady Progress on Major Paving Projects Across Key Roadways
item.dc:creator: Greay Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City made significant progress on several major paving projects, including completed work on Baltic Avenue and ongoing improvements along MLK Boulevard and Atlantic Avenue. Each milestone brought the city closer to safer and smoother streets for everyone.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City made continued progress in enhancing the quality and safety of its roadways through several major paving projects. The initiative aimed to provide smoother, safer, and more reliable travel experiences for residents and visitors alike.

One of the key updates included Baltic Avenue, where the first half of the milling and paving from Maine to Missouri was officially completed. This marked a major milestone in the city’s infrastructure improvement efforts. Work on the remaining section was set to resume once the stretch of inclement weather passed, ensuring that the project would maintain its pace without compromising quality.

At MLK Boulevard, significant concrete, ramp, and sidewalk improvements were underway. These upgrades were designed to make the area more accessible and pedestrian-friendly, paving the way—literally—for the next phase of work, which included milling and paving from Route 30 to Mediterranean Avenue.

Meanwhile, on Atlantic Avenue, preparations were advancing for the Atlantic Avenue Improvement Project, a major undertaking that covered the stretch from Tennessee to Albany Avenues. The Notice to Proceed had already been issued, and construction submissions were under review. Pre-paving activities were scheduled to start in the following weeks, signaling the beginning of one of the city’s most anticipated roadway transformations.

These coordinated efforts represented the city’s ongoing dedication to maintaining and upgrading its infrastructure. By addressing key routes and ensuring the long-term durability of its roads, the City of Atlantic City demonstrated its commitment to both public safety and community progress.

The paving projects not only improved the driving experience but also contributed to better traffic flow and reduced vehicle wear and tear. Residents were encouraged to stay informed about ongoing updates and traffic advisories to plan their commutes accordingly.

With each completed section, Atlantic City moved closer to achieving its goal of a modern, well-maintained roadway network that supports its growing community and bustling tourism sector.

item.title: Waffles with the Nurse: A Heartwarming Community Workshop at Pennsylvania Avenue School
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Public Schools Early Childhood Department hosted Waffles with the Nurse at Pennsylvania Avenue School, combining a delicious breakfast with vital health education to promote wellness, family engagement, and community connection.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Public Schools Early Childhood Department hosted a warm and engaging community event titled Waffles with the Nurse on Wednesday, October 22, 2025, at Pennsylvania Avenue School. The workshop successfully combined delicious breakfast treats with essential health education, creating an atmosphere of learning, care, and connection among parents, staff, and students.

The event was designed to promote family engagement and raise awareness about student health requirements. Parents gathered in the Parent Resource Center, where they enjoyed freshly made waffles, crispy bacon, sausage, and fruit while participating in an informative discussion about school health policies.

Principal Thomas Biggins emphasized the school’s commitment to family involvement and student well-being, saying, “We’re not just a building on the block. One of our cornerstones is parent involvement. Most importantly, we want students to be healthy, and they need to be well.”

School Nurse Sherese Price led the workshop, focusing on vital topics such as immunizations, physicals, and health documentation. She reminded parents to ensure their child’s contact information and medical records are up-to-date and that flu shots and dental records are submitted as required. “We want your child to be in school, every day,” she said.

Nurse Price also discussed the importance of keeping children home when they are sick, outlining clear health guidelines for families. She addressed seasonal illnesses and emerging health concerns such as Hand, Foot and Mouth disease, reinforcing the importance of prevention and early awareness.

“Nurse Price leads with empathy and care,” said Principal Biggins. “Bringing awareness to everything that a nurse does is absolutely critical.”

The event’s welcoming environment was further enriched by the efforts of Parent Resource Center Educator Denise Bowles, who highlighted the center’s role in supporting families. “We take care of the needs of the parents,” Bowles said, explaining that the center offers English as a Second Language (ESL) classes and family-centered programs like Muffins with Moms and Donuts with Dads.

Waffles with the Nurse was more than just a breakfast gathering—it was a celebration of community, health, and collaboration. The event reflected the district’s dedication to supporting families not only academically but also through wellness and engagement initiatives.

Through events like this, Atlantic City Public Schools continues to strengthen the partnership between educators, health professionals, and families, ensuring that every child has the foundation to thrive in both health and learning.

The success of Waffles with the Nurse demonstrated how meaningful outreach and genuine connection can foster stronger relationships, encourage proactive health habits, and build a more supportive school community.

item.title: Atlantic City Receives Diaspora Excellence Award for Championing Cultural Unity
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City and Mayor Marty Small Sr. were honored with the Diaspora Excellence Award from Rediscover Africa 2025 and the Ghanaian Associations, recognizing the city’s enduring commitment to diversity, cultural unity, and inclusion. The award followed the historic Ghana Flag Raising Ceremony, the first of its kind in New Jersey.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City and Mayor Marty Small Sr., together with the City’s Multicultural Services Department, were honored with the Diaspora Excellence Award from Rediscover Africa 2025 and the Ghanaian Associations of South Jersey and Atlantic City.

This distinguished recognition celebrated the city’s long-standing commitment to diversity, cultural unity, and inclusion. The award highlighted how Atlantic City has continued to foster a welcoming environment for all communities, embracing the rich cultural heritage that defines the city’s identity.

The honor stemmed from the city’s landmark Ghana Flag Raising Ceremony held at City Hall in 2023, which marked a historic moment as the first Ghanaian flag raising in the State of New Jersey. The event became a symbol of pride, unity, and respect for cultural traditions.

During that celebration, city officials, Ghanaian community leaders, and residents came together to commemorate not only Ghana’s independence but also the shared values of progress, collaboration, and inclusivity that connect the Ghanaian diaspora and Atlantic City.

The recognition by Rediscover Africa and the Ghanaian Associations underscored the city’s role as a model for multicultural engagement, where cultural diversity is viewed as a strength that enriches civic life.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. expressed gratitude for the award, noting that Atlantic City’s multicultural initiatives are part of an ongoing effort to honor and uplift every community represented in the city.

The Diaspora Excellence Award reaffirmed Atlantic City’s reputation as a city that not only celebrates differences but also builds bridges across cultures. It reflected the administration’s continuous dedication to fostering respect, understanding, and unity among its diverse residents.

item.title: Celebrating Atlantic City’s Business Icons: A Street Dedication to Entrepreneurial Excellence
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue pays tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City for four decades.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City community has been lovin’ longtime Atlantic City McDonald’s owners Rita and Anthony Mack for the last four decades, and they’ve been lovin’ the community right back. And now, the City of Atlantic City has honored these two community icons with a street dedication recognizing their nearly 40 years of business excellence, community impact, and entrepreneurial leadership in the city.

Arctic Avenue between Michigan and Arkansas Avenues has been named Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue, paying tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City, with their first one purchased in June 1986 and final one sold in May 2024 as they embarked on a much-deserved retirement.

The Macks are the definition of successful entrepreneurship in Atlantic City. Long before casinos dominated the city’s economy, there was a generation of African American business leaders who built strong, community-based enterprises that anchored neighborhoods and provided opportunity. Today, as Atlantic City’s Economic Development division under the Department of Planning and Development works to revitalize that same spirit of local ownership and empowerment, the Macks stand as living proof that businesses –especially minority-owned ones - can not only survive but thrive in Atlantic City. Rita and Anthony Mack have been the blueprint for success, showing what’s possible through hard work, generosity, and a deep commitment to community.

“We really appreciate your many years of service, your selfless service, and your dedication to the Great City of Atlantic City community," Mayor Small told the Macks during the Street Dedication Ceremony in their honor. It was during this ceremony that the couple also received a custom street sign to take home, symbolizing the enduring legacy they have built.

Rita and Anthony Mack expressed deep gratitude for the recognition and for the community that supported them from the beginning.

“We are incredibly honored and humbled to receive this awesome recognition,” said Rita Mack. “The renaming of this city block to Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue is an undeniable dream for us. It’s the very block where we began our business journey in 1986, and we are thrilled beyond belief.”

Reflecting on their journey, Rita added:

“They say the most critical factors in choosing a franchise are location, location, location. I must say, we struck gold when we purchased our Arkansas Avenue site. But we were also blessed to find ourselves in a supportive and caring community. From the very beginning, this community has embraced and supported us in so many ways.”

The Macks hope that others — especially young people and aspiring entrepreneurs — will be inspired each time they pass Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue, a lasting reminder that dreams can be built right here in Atlantic City.

Their name now rightfully takes its place in the heart of Atlantic City in recognition of their extraordinary contributions.

item.title: Deadline Approaching! Atlantic City Invites Small Businesses to Apply for Micro Grant Program—Up to $15,000 Available
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City is now accepting applications for its Small Business Micro Grant Program, offering up to $15,000 in funding to help local entrepreneurs recover and grow. Applications are open until October 31, 2025, and can be submitted online, by email, or in person through the Department of Planning & Development.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City is once again investing in its small business community through the Small Business Micro Grant Program, offering eligible for-profit businesses the chance to receive up to $15,000 in grant funding. Made possible through over $400,000 in federal funding from the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), this initiative aims to help local businesses recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, retain jobs, and strengthen long-term growth.

The program supports both existing small businesses and startups operating within Atlantic City limits. Funds can be used for a range of operational costs—including payroll, rent, mortgage, utilities, equipment, inventory, and other pandemic-related expenses incurred between March 3, 2021, and October 1, 2023. Startups established in 2022 or later may also qualify.

“This program continues to fulfill Mayor Marty Small, Sr.’s vision of strengthening Atlantic City’s local economy by supporting small businesses,” said Bruce Weekes, Assistant Director of Economic Development. “We encourage all eligible businesses—especially those that have previously participated in city programs—to apply and take advantage of this funding opportunity.”

Who Can Apply:
To qualify, applicants must:
  • Be a for-profit business located in Atlantic City (or planning to locate there)
  • Employ 50 or fewer people
  • Be independently owned and operated
  • Be registered in New Jersey
  • Provide documentation showing financial hardship due to the pandemic

Startups must also submit a current business plan and a short narrative explaining how COVID-19 affected their operations.

How to Apply:
Applications are now open and will be accepted until October 31, 2025. Early submission is strongly encouraged, as applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis.

Applicants must submit a completed application packet in one of the following ways:

  1. By Email: Send your full application to bweekes@acnj.gov
  2. By Mail or In Person:
    Department of Planning & Development
    Attn: Bruce Weekes
    1301 Bacharach Blvd., Suite 506
    Atlantic City, NJ 08401

Application materials and full program guidelines, including a list of required documents for both existing businesses and startups, can be downloaded from www.acnj.gov or picked up in person at the address above.

For any questions or to confirm eligibility, applicants are encouraged to contact Bruce Weekes directly by email or by calling 609-347-5544. Those visiting in person are asked to reach out ahead of time to arrange pickup.

This program is part of the Small Administration’s ongoing commitment to supporting small businesses, increasing economic diversity, and helping entrepreneurs succeed in Atlantic City. It complements other free programs offered through the Economic Development Division, including the Small Business Academy, Credit Repair Program, Investment Cohort, and marketing workshops designed to help business owners grow with little-to-no budget.

With programs like these, Atlantic City continues to prove that it’s a place to live, work, and thrive—where small businesses can turn ideas into success stories and help drive the city’s bright economic future.

item.title: Atlantic City to Launch Food Truck Operations at Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City will launch its new food truck operations on November 1, 2025, at Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park, creating fresh opportunities for small businesses and offering residents and visitors more local dining options in two of the city’s most vibrant public spaces.
item.content:encoded:
Get ready to taste something new in Atlantic City! Starting November 1, 2025, the city will officially launch its food truck operations at two popular public destinations—Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park—bringing more dining variety, energy, and opportunity to the community.

Approved unanimously by City Council earlier this year, this initiative reflects Atlantic City’s growing commitment to supporting small businesses and enhancing its outdoor spaces. The Office of Economic Development and Department of Planning & Development have been working closely with Public Works and Licensing & Inspection to prepare each site with new signage, designated vendor spaces, and clear operating guidelines to ensure a smooth launch.

At O’Donnell Memorial Park, food trucks will be positioned along Captain John O’Donnell Parkway, offering easy access for residents and visitors exploring the area. Meanwhile, at Gardner’s Basin, trucks will operate along the roadway between the Seawall parking lot and the Atlantic City Aquarium, providing guests with convenient and delicious options by the water.

Each location will accommodate up to eight registered and approved food trucks, operating daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM. Interested vendors can now apply through the City of Atlantic City website at www.acnj.gov. Applications open on October 6, 2025, under the Licensing & Inspection section—simply select Food Truck under Business Licenses/Mercantile.

“This is another exciting step in showing that Atlantic City is open for business,” said Mayor Marty Small, Sr. “We’re creating opportunities for small businesses, generating tax revenue, and giving residents and visitors more affordable food options in two of our most visited public areas.”

Bruce Weekes, Assistant Director of Economic Development, added, “Residents have asked for this for years—and we listened. Our goal is for this program to serve as a stepping stone for food operators to establish themselves right here in Atlantic City, grow their brands, and eventually open permanent storefronts.”

All participating food trucks will be inspected and approved by the City of Atlantic City Health Department and the Atlantic City Fire Department before operation. Vendors will be responsible for maintaining cleanliness and following all city regulations. Please note that the sale of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis is strictly prohibited.

With this new initiative, Atlantic City continues to prove that it’s not just a destination—it’s a community of opportunity, where entrepreneurs can thrive and residents can enjoy diverse, local experiences every day.

item.title: Atlantic City on the Move: Mayor Small and NJDOT Announce Full Repaving of Pacific Avenue and Major Infrastructure Upgrades
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City advances $25M in upgrades—repaving Pacific, Atlantic, Baltic & MLK Blvd, enhancing signals, sidewalks & safety citywide.
item.content:encoded:
The momentum continues. In another milestone for Atlantic City’s infrastructure revitalization, Mayor Marty Small Sr., joined by the New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT), announced the full repaving of Pacific Avenue — one of the city’s most vital transportation corridors — as part of more than $25 million in ongoing infrastructure projects across the city.

‍

$5.3 Million in New Grant Funding Fuels Major Improvements

The New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) recently awarded $5.3 million in new State and Federal grant funding to support several significant projects in Atlantic City, including the full repaving of Pacific Avenue and the construction of new sidewalks connecting Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights — a key safety improvement for students and families.

This funding builds on more than $25 million in active infrastructure projects already underway citywide, including improvements along Atlantic Avenue, Baltic Avenue, Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, and Tennessee Avenue. Together, these investments represent the largest coordinated infrastructure effort the city has seen in decades — aimed at making Atlantic City safer, stronger, and more connected.

“Under the Small Administration, relationships matter — and our strong partnership with state agencies like NJDOT is delivering real results for the people of the Great City of Atlantic City,” said Mayor Small. “This is a historic moment because, for the first time in a very long time, residents and visitors alike will experience newly paved roads through the main arteries of our great city. No previous administration has made this level of progress in such a short time. These grants are helping us transform Atlantic City’s infrastructure, while also making critical safety improvements that benefit everyone.”

“The revitalization of Pacific Avenue has been a priority for Governor Murphy and now that the signal synchronization is under contract, it is important to repave this major corridor from Maine Avenue to Albany Avenue,” said NJDOT Commissioner Fran O’Connor. “This is the gateway to the casino resorts, hotels, businesses, and famed Boardwalk. Building a walkway to link the Atlantic City High School to the city is an important safety improvement.”

‍

Infrastructure Projects Transforming the City

Across Atlantic City, infrastructure upgrades are reshaping the city’s streets, corridors, and connections between neighborhoods. The following projects are currently active:

  • Atlantic Avenue Repaving: From Tennessee to Albany Avenues, including corridor-wide safety and beautification enhancements.
  • Pacific Avenue Signal Optimization Project: Synchronizing 35 traffic signals and installing new fiber-optic infrastructure to improve traffic flow and safety.
  • Baltic Avenue Repaving: From Maine to North Carolina Avenues, with work continuing west to Missouri Avenue and plans for the Fairmount Avenue segment.
  • Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard Repaving: From Route 30 to Mediterranean Avenue, improving access and safety in key residential and commercial zones.
  • Pedestrian Connectivity: The addition of new sidewalks between Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights to improve walkability and student safety.

Building Momentum Across Every Neighborhood

With more than $25 million in infrastructure projects currently underway — and new State and Federal grants expanding the city’s capacity to deliver results — Atlantic City continues to build momentum, modernizing its streets, strengthening neighborhoods, and enhancing quality of life for residents, visitors, and investors alike.

The improvements mean smoother commutes for residents, safer routes for students and families, and modernized corridors that support small businesses and future development.

Atlantic City’s progress is visible in every direction — proof that strategic investment, collaboration, and leadership are paving the way for a stronger, more connected city.

item.title: A New Look, A Great Day: The Reimagined Great Day Gazette Brings Atlantic City Together
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Great Day Gazette celebrates Atlantic City’s growth, unity, and community spirit with the launch of the Great Day app, major development milestones, and vibrant local events—all underscoring that it truly was a Great Day in the City of Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City has officially unveiled its newly rebranded Great Day Gazette, ushering in a new chapter of storytelling, connection, and community pride. What began as an internal newsletter has grown into a dynamic publication that celebrates everything that makes Atlantic City an extraordinary place to live, work, and thrive.

The rebrand comes at an exciting time, aligning with the launch of the Great Day Atlantic City app—a digital platform designed to shine a light on the people, progress, and positive news happening across the city. Together, the Gazette and the app form a powerful communication hub, keeping residents, employees, and visitors informed about all the great things taking place within Atlantic City.

In his opening message, Mayor Marty Small Sr. expressed enthusiasm for the Gazette’s evolution and the city’s renewed focus on positivity and transparency. “There are way too many negative voices out there when it comes to the Great City of Atlantic City,” the Mayor said. “The Great Day platform gives all the positives, which far outweigh the negatives—the spotlight they deserve.”

This month’s issue of the Great Day Gazette is packed with inspiring stories, community highlights, and exciting updates. Readers can look back on the success of Great Day 2025, a day of motivation and team building for city employees dedicated to the memory of Chief of Staff Ernest Coursey. The event featured keynote speaker Nehemiah Davis, who encouraged city staff to focus on growth, resilience, and becoming the best versions of themselves.

The Gazette also covers the city’s presence at the first Atlantic City Strategic Communications Summit, hosted by Stockton University and the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs (DCA). There, the city’s Marketing Team—including Public Information Officer Andrew Kramer, Assistant PIO Adele Polk, Shennita Williams, and Ziggy Chau of Lucky PR—presented Great Day Atlantic City as a leading example of civic storytelling and community engagement. The summit emphasized collaboration and shared messaging across local institutions to build a stronger, unified voice for Atlantic City.

Readers will also find updates on major development and infrastructure projects. Mayor Small joined community leaders for the grand opening of The Seahaus Hotel and Cucina Del Mar, celebrating the continued growth of Atlantic City’s hospitality sector. Meanwhile, the city began the long-anticipated revitalization of Atlantic Avenue—a transformative project that includes new paving, traffic signal upgrades, ADA-compliant ramps, enhanced lighting, and beautification improvements designed to make the corridor safer and more welcoming for all.

Economic opportunity and small business growth are also front and center. The Gazette highlights the Small Business Micro Grant Program, providing reimbursement support for local businesses through federal ARPA funding, and the new food truck program opening two prime locations—Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park—to bring affordable dining options and entrepreneurial opportunities to the community.

In Public Safety News, the friendly rivalry between the Atlantic City Fire Department and Police Department took center stage during the first-ever Mayor’s Cup Softball Game. The community gathered at Pop Lloyd Stadium to cheer on both teams, celebrating camaraderie and civic pride. The issue also recognized newly promoted fire officers and honored the city’s first responders during the Atlantic City 9/11 Memorial Ceremony.

The Gazette continued its tradition of celebrating people and programs that make Atlantic City vibrant—from Senior Appreciation Day and Hispanic Heritage Month celebrations at City Hall, to new youth initiatives including the Youth Theater Program, Girl Scouts sessions, and Little Leapers gymnastics. Each story reflected the city’s ongoing mission to create inclusive, engaging opportunities for all residents—young and old alike.

Looking ahead, the issue also shared details on upcoming events that embody the city’s community spirit, including the Flood Safety Workshop, the Roll Out! Skating Party for National Coming Out Day, the Drive-In Movie & S’mores Night at Bader Field, and the much-anticipated Harvest Town Festival at Gardner’s Basin.

As the city continues to evolve, the Great Day Gazette stands as a symbol of connection and collaboration—highlighting the stories that too often go untold and celebrating the everyday efforts that make Atlantic City stronger. Whether it’s infrastructure progress, employee recognition, or community celebration, the Gazette captures it all.

Mayor Small summed it up best: “No other administration in Atlantic City history has given employees the amount of training, recognition, and opportunity they’re getting right now—and that’s something I’ll never let up on.”

Read the full October 2025 issue of the Great Day Gazette to stay informed, inspired, and connected to the city’s latest achievements and upcoming events. Because here in Atlantic City—every day truly is a Great Day.

item.title: Clean & Safe in Action: Atlantic City’s "Love Caters All" Shines on a Renewed Florida Avenue
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Nancy Claud, owner of Love Caters All on S. Florida Avenue, purchased her property last year. Since then, she has had a front row seat to watch the area transform for the better.
item.content:encoded:
During the Clean & Safe segment of Mayor Marty Small, Sr.’s 2025 State of the City address, he highlighted the city’s continued efforts toenhance public safety by strategically adding police officers to areashistorically plagued by crime.
“We added extra presence on Florida, Georgia, and Bellevue Avenue, which has been a thorn in every administration’s side,” Mayor Small said during his presentation. “But we’re making progress now with our police officers over there.”
One local business owner sees the impact firsthand.
Nancy Claud, owner of Love Caters All at 30 S. Florida Avenue, purchased her property last year. Since then, she has had a front row seat to watch the area transform for the better and credits the improvement in safety as a key factor in her ability to grow her event planning business.
“In the beginning, those of you who know about Florida Avenue, it was a nightmare,” she said. “I went to Mayor Small’s office, and I explained the situation to him, and he addressed it with the Atlantic City Police Department, and every time I called his office, he helped me out, so I thank him for helping get Florida Avenue cleaned.”
With a renewed sense of security, Claud has been able to turn Love Caters All into a full-service business offering planning, decoration, and venue space for weddings and events — especially for clients looking for last-minute solutions. The business also features upstairs suites for overnight accommodation.
“It’s a full package, one-stop shop,” she said with a smile.
Now that safety is less of a concern at her property, Claud says she’s refocusing on her vision: providing elegance and comfort while creating job opportunities for residents.
“I would love for everyone to come to see something the city was missing,” she added. “We would love to host more Black theater – jazz, plays –so that’s something I would love to add to the city. I love Atlantic City. I think it’s a great city with great potential. I wouldn’t choose anywhere else.”
Based on what she's seen happen outside her business, she’s eager for others to witness the changes. “Please come check out Florida Avenue,” Claud said. “It’s a whole new world, and Mayor Small did help.”

item.title: Atlantic City’s Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program: Preparing Residents for Success
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.content:encoded:
For Atlantic City residents looking to build a brighter future, the Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program is here to help. Designed for those who are unemployed, looking to upskill, or seeking better opportunities, the program removes barriers to employment by combining training, career exploration, and hands-on certifications.

What the Program Offers

  • Soft Skills Training – Teamwork, communication, time management, adaptability, problem-solving
  • Workplace Readiness – 16-hour, in-person training required before advanced certification courses
  • Career Exploration with MECA System – Career planning, assessments, and hands-on projects
  • Hospitality Certifications – Courses from the American Hotel & Lodging Educational Institute:
    • Front Desk Representative (CFDR)
    • Guestroom Attendant (CGA)
    • Restaurant Server (CRS)
    • Maintenance Employee (CME)
    • Kitchen Cook (CKC)
    • Breakfast Attendant (CBA)
    • Guest Service Gold
  • Ongoing Support – Job interview referrals, career planning, and resources for long-term employment success

Beyond Skills: Building Careers

The program also provides personal development resources like The Success Profiler, Winning Colors, Financial Success tools, and anxiety management strategies — ensuring participants don’t just land a job, but build sustainable careers.

Why It Matters

The Job Readiness Program reflects Atlantic City’s commitment to workforce development, creating a pipeline of skilled residents ready to contribute to the city’s growth.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Honored Fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department honored fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke with a memorial ceremony at MLK and Atlantic Avenues, marking 55 years since his sacrifice. His legacy lives on through the Atlantic County K-9 Academy and the officers he continues to inspire.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department held a solemn memorial ceremony in honor of fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke at the intersection of MLK and Atlantic Avenues in Atlantic City.

K-9 Officer Burke was tragically gunned down while on duty at that very intersection 55 years ago. Though decades have passed, his memory continued to live on through the Atlantic County K-9 Academy, which was named in his honor.

As one of the first officers to join the newly established K-9 force, Officer Burke left behind a lasting legacy of bravery and dedication. His commitment to service inspired generations of officers who followed in his footsteps.

The memorial ceremony was attended by several recruits from the John “Sonny” Burke Police K-9 Academy, representing the continuation of his work and the strength of the program built in his name.

Dignitaries and leaders in public safety also paid their respects. Attendees included Chief James Sarkos, Public Safety Director Sean Riggin, and Deputy Chiefs Christian Garofalo and Andrew Leonard, each recognizing the enduring impact of Officer Burke’s service and sacrifice.

A ceremonial wreath was dedicated by AC PBA Local 24 President Jules Schwenger, and placed beneath the street sign for Officer John “Sonny” Burke Avenue, ensuring his legacy remains a visible reminder for the community.

Adding a deeply personal touch to the event, three of K-9 Officer Burke’s brothers attended the ceremony. Among them, Greg Burke delivered an emotional speech, moving the crowd with heartfelt words of remembrance and love.

The gathering stood as a testament to the enduring respect and admiration for Officer Burke’s courage, as well as the unbreakable bond between the department, the academy, and the community he served. The memorial not only honored the past but also reaffirmed the department’s commitment to keeping alive the memory of those who gave the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. By remembering K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke, the Atlantic City Police Department ensured that his legacy of service and sacrifice would continue to inspire future generations.

item.title: Atlantic City to Welcome Food Trucks to Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City will soon welcome food trucks to Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park, creating new opportunities for local vendors and fresh dining experiences for the community. Up to eight food trucks per site began operating daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM starting November 1st.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially expanded its food culture by allowing food trucks to operate in two designated locations. Mayor Marty Small announced that the initiative would provide new opportunities for vendors and offer residents and visitors more diverse dining choices.

Food trucks will be permitted to operate at Gardner’s Basin near the Seawall parking lot and at O’Donnell Memorial Park along Captain John O'Donnell Parkway. Both areas were selected to attract locals and tourists while ensuring convenience and accessibility.

Under this new program, up to eight registered and approved food trucks were allowed at each site. The city ensured proper management by clearly marking the vending areas with designated signage.

To accommodate both daytime and evening crowds, the hours of operation were set daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM, beginning on November 1st. This schedule allowed vendors to serve breakfast, lunch, dinner, and late-night snacks.

Applications for interested vendors are available on the City of Atlantic City Government website, by Monday, October 6th (select Food Truck). To be considered, applicants must:

  • Submit a completed application
  • Pay the required application and license fees
  • Provide certificate of insurance

This effort represented part of the city’s broader push to support local businesses and attract more visitors. Food trucks offered unique cuisines, quick service, and a fresh layer of vibrancy to Atlantic City’s community spaces.

Mayor Small emphasized that the program would help small businesses grow while giving residents more affordable dining options. The city also encouraged local vendors to participate, making sure the opportunity supported the community first.

This initiative marks a new chapter for Atlantic City’s public spaces, blending local entrepreneurship with community enjoyment in a way that celebrated both tradition and innovation.

By November, visitors will be able to experience the new offerings and enjoy freshly prepared meals from some of the region’s best mobile kitchens and Atlantic City's vibrant and diverse food cultures.

item.title: Positive Culture Shift for Atlantic City Employees Continues with Mayor Small’s ‘Great Day’ Event
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: The annual 'Great Day' event is Mayor Small's signature initiative to strengthen workforce climate and culture, boost morale, and unite City of Atlantic City employees as one team.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Mayor Marty Small, Sr. has long said that to truly build Atlantic City, the transformation must begin from the inside out. Since becoming mayor in October 2019, he’s turned that vision into action, reshaping the culture of City Hall and setting a new standard for local government. From his first days in office, Mayor Small raised expectations for every department and made accountability a cornerstone of his administration. He’s expanded opportunities for advancement through internal mobility, promotions, and well-earned raises, ensuring that dedicated employees see a future in public service. Just as importantly, he has invested heavily in training programs that give staff unprecedented professional development and the skills needed to better serve Atlantic City taxpayers.

That commitment came into full focus at this year’s Great Day 2025 event held at the Showboat Resort for a third straight year. This is the mayor’s signature initiative to strengthen workforce climate and culture, boost morale, and unite City of Atlantic City employees as one team. It’s the only time each year every city worker gathers under one roof outside city buildings to receive key organizational updates directly from the mayor and gain fresh perspective from nationally recognized outside sources.

This year’s motivational speaker was philanthropist Nehemiah Davis, who shared his inspiring journey from humble beginnings in Philadelphia—where he frequently found himself getting into trouble—to becoming a prominent figure dedicated to helping others transform their lives. Addressing City of Atlantic City employees, Davis encouraged them to write down the affirmation: “I’m committed and focused on making this the best year ever.” He emphasized how mindset shifts can lead to real change and challenged staff to stop saying, “I have to go to work,” and instead embrace the privilege of being able to say, “I get to go to work”— especially in a place like Atlantic City.

Great Day 2025 carried added significance this year, as it was held in memory of the late Chief of Staff Ernest Coursey. Known for his unwavering dedication as a public servant and his deep care for city employees, Coursey left a lasting legacy. In his honor, all staff wore commemorative shirts, and the city announced the upcoming launch of the Coursey Cares Health& Wellness Challenge, an initiative aimed at promoting small, sustainable lifestyle changes that employees can carry with them for life.

‍

Following the professional development portion of the day, employees get to relax and connect at Showboat’s Island Waterpark, and this year was no exception. With more than 700 employees spread across City Hall, the Public Safety Building, the Public Works Yard, and other locations, some staff members rarely cross paths, if ever. But on this one day a year, in the open, informal setting of the waterpark, colleagues can interact, bond, and build stronger relationships. Team building is a cornerstone of the Small Administration. It’s why each department is tasked with organizing its own annual retreat outside the Great Day event, and why Mayor Small personally leads a retreat for his directors.

A recent article from The Press of Atlantic City covering Great Day 2025 failed to spotlight the most critical component of the event, which is Mayor Small’s mission to raise expectations, invest in employee development, and celebrate the city's workforce. Mayor Small is demonstrating that a city government can evolve from within—and Great Day 2025 is a shining example of that transformation. His message is clear: when the workforce is motivated, well-trained, and connected, the entire Atlantic City community reaps the rewards.

‍

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Atlantic Avenue Contract Awarded for Major Improvement Project

During the latest City Council meeting, officials approved a contract with South State, Inc. to carry out the long-anticipated upgrades along Atlantic Avenue, covering the stretch from Tennessee to Albany Avenues. The decision marked a turning point in a project that had been in planning stages for years.

Work is scheduled to begin in October, keeping the initiative on track with the city’s outlined goals. The project aimed to address infrastructure concerns while creating a safer and more accessible roadway for both motorists and pedestrians.

ADA-compliant ramps, high-visibility crosswalks, and improved lighting were among the enhancements designed to make Atlantic Avenue more inclusive for all users.

In addition to the core infrastructure work, the project also incorporated streetscape and beautification elements, reinforcing Atlantic City’s commitment to creating a welcoming and vibrant atmosphere along the corridor.

City leaders described the awarding of the contract as a milestone in a broader effort to modernize Atlantic City’s infrastructure. They highlighted the project as essential to promoting economic development, improving public safety, and enhancing the overall quality of life for residents and visitors alike.

item.title: Atlantic City Firefighters Capture First Ever Mayor’s Cup
