item.description: The Atlantic City Firefighters claimed the First Ever Mayor’s Cup with a commanding 25–7 win over the Police Department at Pop Lloyd Stadium, marking the beginning of a new community tradition.
item.content:encoded:
The First Ever Mayor’s Cup was held on Thursday, September 18, 2025, at the historic Pop Lloyd Stadium, marking the start of what is expected to become an annual tradition in Atlantic City.

The matchup featured two of the city’s most dedicated groups of public servants, the Atlantic City Fire Department and the Atlantic City Police Department, who took to the field not in their uniforms of duty, but as competitors in a spirited game of softball.

On the other side, the Atlantic City Police Department fought hard to keep the score close, showing resilience and passion throughout the contest. Despite their efforts, the Firefighters’ momentum was too strong to overcome.

By the final inning, the outcome was clear. The Firefighters secured the inaugural Mayor’s Cup with a decisive 25–7 victory, earning bragging rights and the honor of being the first champions in the event’s history.

For the players, the game was more than a competition—it was a chance to strengthen bonds, showcase camaraderie, and give the community an exciting evening of entertainment.

Spectators cheered passionately, applauding every play and enjoying the good-natured rivalry between the city’s first responders. Many expressed pride in seeing both departments come together for an event that highlighted unity and service.

Organizers and city officials praised the success of the event, noting the strong turnout and positive response from the community. They emphasized that the Mayor’s Cup will return in future years, building on the foundation laid at this first matchup.

item.title: Now Open: Applications for Small Business Micro Grant Program in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City Government completed its Small Business Micro Grant Program, providing grants of up to $15,000 to help local businesses recover from the impact of the pandemic. Supported by federal ARPA funding, the program closed its applications on October 31, 2025.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City recently launched its Small Business Micro Grant Program, an initiative created to provide financial relief to local businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The program was made possible through more than $400,000 in federal funding from the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), ensuring that small, for-profit businesses within the city limits had the resources needed to recover.

Eligible businesses received grants of up to $15,000, which supported their ability to manage financial hardships, retain jobs, and strengthen long-term resiliency in the wake of pandemic challenges.

Funds were available for critical expenses such as payroll, rent, mortgage, utilities, equipment, inventory, and operational costs incurred between March 3, 2021, and October 1, 2023.

The program also recognized the unique struggles of new entrepreneurs. Startups and newer businesses established in 2022 or later were given the opportunity to apply, ensuring both longstanding and emerging businesses had access to support.

In addition to direct grants, the initiative included a reimbursement-based program for existing businesses, allowing them to recover costs already paid during the eligible timeframe.

To qualify, businesses were required to be for-profit, independently owned, located in Atlantic City, registered in New Jersey, employ 50 or fewer people, and provide documentation of financial hardship caused by the pandemic.

Full program guidelines and applications are accessible through the city’s official website, giving business owners clear instructions and resources to navigate the process.

‍

The application process officially closes on October 31, 2025.

The application and additional information can be found on the City's website here: https://tinyurl.com/jbj86j5x

item.title: The Seahaus Hotel and Cucina Del Mar Celebrated Grand Opening on the Atlantic City Boardwalk
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City celebrated the grand opening of The Seahaus Hotel and Cucina Del Mar on the Boardwalk, marking a milestone as the first Marriott brand hotel in the city. The event highlighted new opportunities, jobs, and growth for the community.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, milestones are not just about buildings — they are about progress, pride, and possibility. The opening of The Seahaus Hotel and its signature restaurant, Cucina Del Mar, marked more than the debut of a stunning property on the Boardwalk. It was a sign of Atlantic City’s continued growth as a community where people can live, work, and thrive.

A City of Firsts

‍
As a Marriott brand hotel in Atlantic City, The Seahaus brought with it a new level of hospitality and service that aligned with the city’s reputation as a premier coastal destination. Its arrival added depth to the local economy and gave both visitors and residents a fresh reason to experience the Boardwalk in a new way.

Jobs. Opportunity. Growth.

‍
The significance of The Seahaus was never just about its architecture or amenities. It was about what it offered to the people of Atlantic City. With new jobs created and new opportunities in hospitality and dining, the project provided a boost to the local workforce while welcoming guests from across the region.

A Place to Stay, a Place to Gather

‍
The addition of Cucina Del Mar turned The Seahaus into more than a hotel — it became a gathering place. With its unique flavors and welcoming atmosphere, the restaurant added to Atlantic City’s diverse dining scene, giving locals another space to connect and visitors a reason to return.

Partnerships That Build a City

‍
The grand opening celebrated not only the hotel itself but also the collaboration behind it. Coury Hospitality and partners worked closely with city leaders to bring this vision to life, demonstrating what can be achieved when business and community come together.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
What made this moment truly special was how it reflected Atlantic City’s ongoing story. This is a city that values growth and reinvention, while never losing sight of its greatest asset: its people. Projects like The Seahaus show why Atlantic City is not just a destination for tourists — it is a community where opportunity takes root.

‍

A City to Live and Work

‍
For residents, The Seahaus represented more than a new hotel on the Boardwalk. It was part of a bigger picture: companies investing in Atlantic City, its workforce, and its future. Whether through new jobs, new dining experiences, or new partnerships, Atlantic City continues to be a place where people can build careers, raise families, and contribute to a vibrant community.

Looking Ahead

‍
Every opening, every investment, and every milestone adds another layer to the story of Atlantic City. The Seahaus was one chapter, but the larger story is about a city on the move — one that is showing the world what locals have always known: Atlantic City is a place to live, to work, and to belong.

item.title: Atlantic City High School Annual Club Fair Brought Students Together
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City High School’s annual club fair brought students, teachers, and staff together for a day of discovery and connection. The event offered opportunities for involvement, growth, and community.
item.content:encoded:
The annual club fair at Atlantic City High School took place recently and brought together students, faculty, and staff for a day of exploration and connection.

The event was designed to introduce students to the wide range of extracurricular activities available on campus. From academic clubs to athletic organizations, from arts and performance groups to service-oriented associations, the fair showcased opportunities that allowed students to find their place and pursue their passions.

Students walked through the event, stopping by tables set up by various organizations. Each booth provided information about their activities, upcoming events, and the ways new members could get involved.

The club fair was not only a chance to recruit new members but also an opportunity for student leaders to demonstrate the creativity, teamwork, and dedication behind their organizations.

Teachers and advisors were also present, supporting their students and sharing how these extracurricular groups contribute to the overall learning experience at Atlantic City High School.

For many students, this event marked the beginning of a new journey—whether it was joining a club that aligned with their future career goals or discovering a hidden talent through the arts or athletics.

The atmosphere was filled with excitement and curiosity as students engaged with one another, asked questions, and learned about activities they had not considered before.

The fair highlighted the importance of student involvement beyond the classroom, emphasizing that leadership, teamwork, and community engagement are as valuable as academic achievement.

By the end of the day, many students had signed up for new clubs and felt more connected to the school community. The event succeeded in showing that Atlantic City High School is more than just a place of learning—it is a place of growth, exploration, and opportunity.

The annual club fair stood as a reminder of the school’s commitment to fostering a vibrant and supportive environment for every student.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City to the Ivy League, Native Proves ‘This City Doesn’t Limit You’
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Sophia Mammucari’s journey began in the heart of Atlantic City where, as a student at Atlantic City High School, she began to dream big and build the foundation that would carry her all the way to Harvard University.
item.content:encoded:
When Sophia Mammucari tells young people in Atlantic City, “This city doesn’t limit you,” she’s not just offering encouragement—she’s living proof of what’s possible.

Now a sophomore at Harvard University, Mammucari’s journey began in the heart of Atlantic City. Despite moving frequently during her early years, her family ultimately made Atlantic City home. It was there, as a student at Atlantic City High School, that she began to dream big and build the foundation that would carry her all the way to the Ivy League.

“Getting into Harvard was the best day of my life,” she said.

Mammucari is not only thriving academically, but she’s also giving back to the city that raised her. This summer, she returned home to intern with the City of Atlantic City Mayor’s Office and Business Administration Office, where she gained firsthand experience in how municipal government functions.

“I just wanted to learn how government works,” she explained. “I saw the full process, and it was full circle. My journey ended with the City Council meeting, so I saw how ordinances were written, how issues were addressed, all of the meetings that go into it, all the planning, and how there isn’t always a simple answer to everything. The Business Administrator (Anthony Swan) and Mayor (Small) really do work to address all concerns that come to City Hall.”

Through programs like CitiStat, which allows residents to report and track issues through data-driven governance, Mammucari got to see how committed the city is to its own revitalization.

“I was impressed by how much work is being done to improve Atlantic City and to create a real renaissance,” she added.

Mammucari’s connection to the Small administration runs deeper than her internship. She is also a previous recipient of the Mayor Marty Small, Sr. Scholarship, three-year, $3 million initiative supporting Atlantic City students in their pursuit of higher education.

“The scholarships helped me with my expenses during college and made it possible to go to Harvard and excel there,” she said.

‍

While she’s currently making her mark in Boston, Mammucari hasn’t forgotten where she came from. She hopes to one day return to Atlantic City and introduce her organization, The Higher EDvantage, to local students. The nonprofit offers guidance and support for those pursuing college or another form of higher education.

And her ambitions don’t stop there. Could “Mayor Mammucari” be in the city’s future?

“I don’t want to take Mayor Small’s job,” she said with a smile. “But maybe when he retires, I’d love to run for a government position.”

For now, Mammucari remains focused on her education—and on serving as a role model for the next generation of Atlantic City youth.

“I hope I can be someone local students look up to,” she said. “I always encourage kids—especially those from low-income backgrounds or who go to Atlantic City High School—to dream big. You may not think you’re capable, but the answer is always going to be no if you don’t try.”

If anyone ever doubts her hometown or says something negative about it, Mammucari is ready to set the record straight! And she now has the inside experience to back her stance and looks forward to sharing with the world why she is proud to be from Atlantic City and just how much potential this city truly has.

‍

item.title: Celebrating Business Excellence: Dock’s Oyster House Honored by City of Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City – Government honored Dock’s Oyster House with the Business Excellence Award as part of the “Keep It Local” campaign, recognizing its century-long commitment to quality, tradition, and community. Chef Stephan Johnson praised the hands-on leadership of the Dougherty family, crediting them for the restaurant’s enduring success.
item.content:encoded:
Celebrating Business Excellence in Atlantic City

In Atlantic City, summer isn’t only about the boardwalk, beaches, and entertainment — it’s also a season to celebrate community pride and local achievement. Through the “Keep It Local” campaign, the City of Atlantic City recognized small businesses that played a vital role in shaping the city’s economy and identity.

At the heart of this celebration was the Business Excellence Award, presented to one of the city’s most iconic establishments: Dock’s Oyster House.

A Legacy of Excellence
Since opening its doors in 1897, Dock’s Oyster House had remained true to its mission — to serve the finest meals in a welcoming atmosphere. Generations of the Dougherty family guided the restaurant through expansion and transformation, while staying rooted in the values that made it a cornerstone of Atlantic City’s dining scene.

A Dining Experience That Lasts Generations
Guests at Dock’s enjoyed both tradition and innovation. The Pan Sauteed Crab Cakes and Crispy Wasabi Tuna, highlighted by Executive Chef Stephan Johnson, were just two examples of dishes that continued to delight visitors year after year. The restaurant also became known for one of the most popular happy hours in town, drawing both locals and visitors together in celebration of good food and community spirit.

Hands-On Leadership
For more than two decades, Chef Johnson had been a part of Dock’s story. He praised the Dougherty family for their dedication and leadership, noting how their hands-on involvement kept the restaurant not only successful but deeply connected to its community. Their commitment reflected why Dock’s stood as a natural choice for the Business Excellence Award.

Why Atlantic City Believes in Its Businesses
Just as the city invests in its youth, neighborhoods, and culture, it also honors the businesses that bring Atlantic City to life. Local restaurants, shops, and services are more than places of commerce — they are spaces where traditions thrive, opportunities grow, and families build memories.

A Place to Live and Work
The recognition of Dock’s Oyster House illustrated what made Atlantic City such a vibrant place to live and work. It was a city that celebrated its history while embracing the future, supporting small businesses while welcoming visitors from around the world.

A Community That Thrives Together
Every summer, Atlantic City didn’t just showcase its attractions — it highlighted its people. From entrepreneurs and business owners to chefs and community leaders, the city recognized those who contributed to making Atlantic City not only a destination, but a true community.

The Business Excellence Award stood as a reminder that in Atlantic City, success was shared, tradition was honored, and the spirit of community was always at the center.

item.title: Atlantic City Marks September 11 with Community Remembrance
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City community gathered at the Saracini-O’Neill 9/11 Memorial to honor the lives lost on September 11, 2001.
item.content:encoded:
Hundreds of residents, families, and first responders gathered this morning at the Saracini-O’Neill 9/11 Memorial on Jackson Avenue and the Boardwalk for an hour-and-a-half ceremony honoring the nearly 3,000 lives lost in the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks.

Standing together in solidarity, the Atlantic City Police Department (ACPD) and Atlantic City Fire Department (ACFD) joined city and county officials, Mayor Marty Small Sr., members of the Ventnor Police and Fire Departments, and the Egg Harbor Township Fire Department. The gathering provided a time of reflection and unity, recognizing both the victims and the first responders who rushed toward danger that day.

The ceremony included songs, poems, and art. A 40-ton patriotic sand sculpture by artist John Gowdy and a massive American flag raised by ACFD ladder trucks framed the memorial. Music from the Sandpipers Pipes & Drums of Atlantic County added to the solemn atmosphere, while an Honor Guard of ACPD and ACFD members presented the colors.

Among those honored were Angel and Camille Morales, retired NYPD officers who responded to Ground Zero on September 11 and now live in Atlantic City. Their presence underscored the continuing connection between the city and the heroism displayed 24 years ago.

Mayor Small addressed the crowd, reflecting on resilience, healing, and the importance of remembrance. ACPD Chief James Sarkos and ACFD Chief Scott Evans spoke of the sacrifices made and the duty to support one another in service and in community.

Atlantic City’s annual September 11 memorial reaffirms the city’s commitment to never forget—honoring the past while strengthening the bonds of community that carry forward.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Honored with Operations 803 Award for Human
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department honored its officers with the Operations 803 Award for dismantling a major human trafficking operation, rescuing two juveniles, and bringing suspects into custody.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department (ACPD) proudly recognized the exceptional work of its officers and detectives who received the Operations 803 Award for their outstanding efforts in a major human trafficking investigation.

On March 30, 2025, ACPD officers and detectives, acting on information provided by the New York Police Department (NYPD), worked tirelessly to locate two missing juveniles and to dismantle a dangerous criminal operation. Their mission demanded persistence, teamwork, and dedication, ultimately leading to the safe recovery of the victims.

Through coordinated efforts, ACPD identified and apprehended multiple suspects involved in the operation. During the investigation, officers also recovered narcotics, further dismantling the network’s illicit activities. The safe return of the juveniles to their families stood as a testament to the officers’ commitment and determination.

The scale of the investigation drew the involvement of State and Federal authorities, resulting in 1st degree Human Trafficking charges being filed against the suspects. This milestone underscored the significance of ACPD’s role in ensuring justice and safeguarding vulnerable victims.

The Operations 803 Award was created to honor officers who display initiative, resilience, and leadership that inspires others to uphold the highest standards of service. The award was named in honor of Officer Josh Lee Vadell, whose courage in the face of life-altering injuries continued to inspire the ACPD family and community.

Among the recipients were Detectives Leah McHale, Adrianna Petinga, and Mitzi Cruz, along with Officers Juan Garcia, Julian Monsalve, James Eckert, Brandon Bower, Dylan Imbrenda, John Bell, Robert Thompson, and Andrew Xiques. Their actions reflected extraordinary dedication to duty and unwavering commitment to protecting the community.

The recognition also highlighted ACPD’s strong collaboration with partner agencies, reinforcing the importance of interdepartmental coordination in addressing crimes that span beyond city borders. The case served as a powerful example of what law enforcement could achieve when working together.

Mayor Marty Small, Sr. and community leaders expressed gratitude to the officers for their bravery and professionalism. The acknowledgment of their work demonstrated Atlantic City’s commitment to both public safety and the pursuit of justice.

The award ceremony served not only as recognition but also as a reminder of the risks law enforcement officers take daily to protect their communities. The officers’ resilience and courage set a benchmark for others within the ACPD. Operations 803 Award symbolized the ACPD’s dedication to serving with honor, protecting the most vulnerable, and inspiring confidence within the community they swore to serve.

item.title: Mayor Small Announced Relocation of Atlantic City’s Former Chelsea Beach Bar
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City
item.description: Mayor Marty Small, Sr. announced the relocation of the former Chelsea Beach Bar to a new site outside Jim Whelan Boardwalk Hall, ensuring balance between Atlantic City’s entertainment scene and residents’ quality of life.
item.content:encoded:
Mayor Marty Small, Sr. announced that the long-running beach bar once known as Chelsea Beach Bar—most recently operating as Cocorico Beach Bar and Goldfish Beach Bar—will relocate to a new home before the 2026 summer season.

The Move

The bar will move to the beach between Bellevue and Georgia Avenues, just steps from Jim Whelan Boardwalk Hall.
The decision, made jointly by the City of Atlantic City and the bar’s owners and approved by the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs (DCA), reflects a thoughtful approach to growth:

  • Better fit for the neighborhood: The new site is set apart from similar venues and away from residential properties.
  • Continued energy on the beach: Visitors and locals will still enjoy the vibrant atmosphere that the beach bar has brought to the shoreline for years.

Mayor Small emphasized the balance behind the move:

“This is the best move for all parties. The beach bar will continue to add to Atlantic City’s entertainment scene, while nearby residents can enjoy more peace in front of their homes.”

Next Steps

The relocation has the support of the DCA, the City’s Business Administrator and Solicitor’s Office, and the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP). The plan will now head to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority (CRDA) for final land-use approval.

What It Means for Atlantic City

This move highlights Atlantic City’s commitment to smart shoreline development—one that supports local business while safeguarding neighborhood quality of life.

‍
It’s another example of how the city is shaping a dynamic, welcoming beachfront for residents and visitors alike.
